metadata.title: The Simpsons is the Best TV show to Learn English Words | Towards Data Science
metadata.h1: The Simpsons is the Best TV show to Learn English Words
metadata.description: The Simpsons help you learn more English words than TV shows like Friends and Game of Thrones. Find which Simpsons 679 episodes are the best for basic and advanced English students.

outgoing_paragraph_urls.anchor_text: The Best 100 Movies to Learn English

all_paragraphs: With thirty-two seasons entertaining millions of people, The Simpsons is considered one of the greatest TV shows of all time. But have you ever thought that this TV show could make you take your English vocabulary to the next level? This is true, especially if you’re learning English as a second language. In this article, I’ll prove this to you by comparing the vocabulary within dialogues in 83 popular TV shows, including Friends, Game of Thrones, The Big Bang Theory, Grey’s Anatomy and more. You’ll also know which Simpsons 679 episodes are the best for you to learn English.

Have you ever wondered how do you learn new words through watching TV shows? It’s by repetition. You hear a word in one episode, and then you hear it more times in the TV show during the week. Then voila! You just learned a new word! This is what makes The Simpsons unique. It has the highest number of repetitions in advanced English vocabulary. Some studies say that at least 6 times is the number of repetitions or exposure to a word before you learn it, while others say it’s 17 times. With the transcripts of almost all episodes from 83 TV shows, I calculated the number of words repeated at least 10 (average between the two studies) times in the dialogues.

The Simpsons is by far the TV show with more advanced words repeated ten or more times (1929 words from level 4 and above). The Simpsons more than tripled advanced words repeated 10 or more times in series such as Friends, Game of Thrones and The Big Bang Theory. Find your favorite TV show in the plot below.

Now you may think, ‘If The Simpsons have more total runtime than most TV shows, then makes sense that it has more word repetition’ This is true, but this is not the only reason why this happens. If you check carefully, you’ll find two TV shows with even more runtime than The Simpsons but less repetition. Besides, the first 16 seasons of The Simpsons have more vocabulary repetition than TV shows with less or more runtime.

Research suggests that 1000 most common word families (Level 1) in English cover 81.54% of the vocabulary in a movie and 85.11% of the vocabulary in TV programs. Later, I’ll show you that the most common 3000-word families (Level 3) cover 94% of the dialogues in a Simpsons episode, but first, let’s see those difficult words from Level 4 and above within Simpsons dialogues. Spoiler alert, you may find lots of slang!

Before you start wondering why the words on the left don’t seem so difficult, you must know that they're actually the most common words from level 4 and above in all Simpsons episodes. That is, the words in the first wordcloud are the easiest within level 4 and above. In contrast, the ones on the right are the least common advanced words repeated at least 10 times.

Whether you’re a beginner, intermediate or advance English learner, you might’ve felt frustrated at least once in your life because you didn’t understand a joke your favorite character told. I have good news for you; I ranked all Simpsons episodes by difficulty as I did in The Best 100 Movies to Learn English. The episodes furthest to the right cover more basic (Lvl 1) or intermediate (Lvl 1+2+3) vocabulary. The higher the coverage, the easier to understand a Simpsons episode.
Hover on the dots in the plot to find what’s the next Simpsons episode you’re going to watch!

I found that the episode Secrets of A Successful Marriage (Season 5-Episode 22) covers the highest percentage of level 1 vocabulary, which means that this episode is probably the one you’d understand dialogues easily. However, you’d probably have a hard time trying to understand the jokes from the episodes furthest to the left like Redneck and Broomsticks (Season 21-Episode 7) and Sideshow Bob’s Last Gleaming (Season 7-Episode 9).
This is a clip from the episode Secrets of A Successful Marriage available on my YouTube channel. If you speak or study English, you’ll notice that the dialogues are very simple.
These are the top 10 episodes from The Simpsons with the easiest English vocabulary:

If I convinced you of the potential for increasing your English vocabulary with The Simpsons, then you should consider checking the following table every time you watch a new episode. Before watching a Simpsons episode, you can find out which difficult words you’ll hear by searching in the box below. You can filter by word, episode or season.
Look up the definition of any word you find difficult before you watch a new episode and you’d increase the chances of understanding jokes next time you watch The Simpsons!

Naturally, Homer, Marge, Bart and Lisa Simpson have more lines than the rest of the characters — that’s why the show is called The Simpsons, right? However, none of the four main characters use complex sentences in their lines. Actually, the characters with less screentime such as Burns, Skinner, Krusty and Flanders are the ones who tend to use more advanced vocabulary. Are they the smartest characters for you?

The average.number of spoken words in a Simpsons episode is 2,472 words. Most of the vocabulary used in Simpsons dialogues belong to the most common 1000 English words. This happens with most TV shows; then it’s easy to acquire level 1 and level 2 vocabulary for non-native English speakers by watching TV shows. However, most TV shows have a little advanced vocabulary in a single episode. Fortunately, a few TV shows like The Simpsons have many words repeated at least 10 times throughout all episodes, which helps build advanced vocabulary.
Finally, a few observations about the transcripts and the vocabulary levels:

If you’d like to see the code behind this analysis, you can find it here. Remember that vocabulary is not the only factor in obtaining a good understanding of TV shows. Pronunciation, accent and speech pace might increase or decrease your level of comprehension as well.
I have to admit that I’m not a big Simpsons fan, but after finding the benefits this TV shows offer, I’ll consider watching it whenever I have free time! What episode should I start watching?
